history.subtitle: Explore the long journey of Batak script, an ancient writing heritage that lives on today.

ancient.title: Ancient Era
ancient.description: Batak script is believed to be derived from the Brahmi script that developed in ancient India. Its spread to the archipelago is thought to have been through the Pallawa script and Kawi script (Ancient Javanese). Language and philology experts conclude that Batak script has the closest kinship with other ancient scripts in Sumatra.

colonial.title: Colonial Era
colonial.description: This script was mainly mastered by the datu (spiritual leaders and shamans). They used Batak Script to write pustaha laklak, which are books made from tree bark containing magical knowledge, predictions, traditional medicine, and genealogical records.

modern.title: Modern Era
modern.description: Although its use in daily life has greatly diminished, awareness to preserve Batak script as an invaluable cultural heritage began to grow in the modern era. Through these efforts, it is hoped that Batak script will not only become a historical record, but can continue to live and be part of Batak cultural identity in the future.
